posts.text:
Looks good, which is what I expect of you, fiddletown. As for the cp argument, I realize whether or not it holds is far from certain. Part of the problem is whether or not cp or sp is being used. You may very well have a much better handle on marital property law and I will be the first to admit that I don't. It is hard enough make any sense out of CA law, but throw in community property issues and . . .
Re FC 1100, the fact that one has the power of disposition over CP as if it was that spouse's SP is not to say it is SP. For instance my wife has SP. She has authorized me to dispose of it, but if I did so it would still be her SP being disposed.
Were someone foolish enough to retain me to argue a case for their defense, I might take the position that this is not a case in which in order to serve the intent of the law that for should be cast aside to be replaced by substance. I would point out where Abramski discusses in dictum that the the law was meant to cover sales on the secondary market nor gifts. That the driver behind Ambraski was the idea that the ultimate gun owner should undego a background check. In many states there is none if the firearm is not resold by a dealer. In California there is still not as complete a screening of the giftee if they be a spouse and both spouses are CA resident, but at lest there is some screening since the transfer has to be reported on an OP LAW to the DOJ.
I just saw the post accusing you of rudeness. I wouldn't say that you pull any punches and haven't been known to be a bit brusque, but not sure that I would say rude. Do you think the guy ever even read Abramski, because he definitely doesn't understand it and I have been unable to get him to say that he read the decision.
I see that the kid thinks there is something wrong with commenting on suspicions based on evidence. I wonder what he thinks a jury does. Even then the OP never said that my take on what he was doing was off the mark.

thread.title_full: Don't Make Mrs. Clause a Felon - Calguns.net

posts.author: fiddletown
posts.text:
Quote: : ... I think that any evidence that a spouse is being used to DROS a firearm to mask the identity of the true purchaser could be found to be a straw purchase. Perhaps in the light of day I may begrudgingly agree that the mere use of cp by one spouse to buy a gun as a gift for the other is not enough to establish a straw purchase. I am not so sure of the results if there is evidence that for any reason the one spouse is avoiding a DROS. Okay, I think that's an important, but subtle point. The issue under federal law is whether the person doing the paperwork is the actual buyer or only the agent of the actual buyer. The source of the money can be evidence probative of an agency relationship. There could be other facts that would establish such relationship other than or in addition to the source of funds. So the question breaks down into two parts: (1) What's going on?; and (2) What is the evidence that leads one to the conclusion that's what's going on?
The thing is that in California, the source of funds isn't that useful when the person doing the paperwork is a spouse and the money is community property. In other words the use of community funds is not evidence that the spouse is acting as the agent of the other spouse because the spouse doing the paperwork is perfectly free to use community funds as his/her own.
In California there's also the problem of the transaction being a sham in violation of 27515 and 27520 to avoid a dealer transfer under 27545. But again the use of community funds can't really be evidence of that because the spouse doing the paperwork is perfectly free to use community funds as his/her own.
In either case a use of community funds isn't really evidence of a 18 USC 922(a)(6) or PC 27515/27520 violation. If a prosecutor suspects such a violation he'll need other evidence to get a conviction.

Sure, there is nothing wrong with him paying for both and waiting the 30 days to DROS gun #2 for himself, but having the wife come in and "buy" it just so the husband doesn't have to wait is begging for trouble.
You don't have to convince anyone that you are confused. Your interpretation of what he is doing boggles the imagination . . . running an errand for someone is BS. . . he mentioned waiting the 30 days to put it in his name for the simple reason that the gun is for him and not his wife . . . that he thought that what you call "dropping off a deposit" was buyhing the gun evidences his intention to buy it for himself . . . there is no face to face if the wife does the DROS application since she is not the actual buyer. At this point the release of the deposit to the husband and payment by the wife would only establish that they realized they were in violation and an attempt to conceal the same.

posts.author: feedback.english@eenadudigital.com (EenaduIndia)
posts.title: Goa govt relieves DIG amid corruption allegations
posts.text: Goa govt relieves DIG amid corruption allegations Published 07-Dec-2017 13:15 IST Maximum Length : 250 File Photo Panaji: The Goa government has relieved the state's Deputy Inspector General of Police (DIG), Vimal Kumar Gupta, following allegations of corruption against him. Gupta was relieved from his post on December 5 and directed to report to the Union Ministry of Home Affairs. Last week, a woman police sub-inspector and a constable were suspended after they allegedly offered bribe to Gupta to the inquiry into complaints against them. The constable was facing a departmental inquiry in a case related to indiscipline. Besides, a departmental inquiry was on against the sub-inspector after she along with another constable allegedly assaulted a man near Panaji in 2014 and took away his car. "The DIG was relieved by the state government and he will report to the Union Ministry of Home Affairs, following allegations of bribery against him," Goa Chief Minister Manohar Parrikar told reporters here yesterday. "The departmental inquiries conducted by Gupta would be reviewed by a senior officer who will take charge of the matter," he said. Parrikar said Gupta has been relieved but that does not mean he has been given a clean chit in the matter.

thread.title: Labour NEC Ballot: Vote Left
thread.title_full: Labour NEC Ballot: Vote Left

posts.author: Anonymous
posts.text:
Plus this wonderful quote from The Man Himself when he was young:

Tony Blair: http://www.lrb.co.uk/v09/n19/tony-blair/diary

“ But there is nothing more ridiculous than the notion that socialism is inexorably dying, or has been compulsorily retired on grounds of redundancy. Socialism, as its name suggests, is based on a belief in the notion of action through the community, in the idea that individuals do not stand alone, and that it is not merely morally right that we should think of ourselves in this way but that it is the most rational way to organise our lives. The world we face today makes a socialist approach all the more relevant: from new technology to the arms race, co-operation surely makes more sense than competition. ”
“ Post-war Britain has seen two big changes. First, and partly as a result of reforming Labour governments, there are many more healthy, wealthy and well-educated people than before. In addition, employment has switched from traditional manufacturing industries to a more white-collar, service-based economy. The inevitable result has been that class identity has fragmented. Only about a third of the population now regard themselves as ‘working-class’. Of course it is possible still to analyse Britain in terms of a strict Marxist definition of class: but it is not very helpful to our understanding of how the country thinks and votes. In fact, of that third, many are likely not to be ‘working’ at all: these are the unemployed, pensioners, single parents – in other words, the poor.
A party that restricts its appeal to the traditional working class will not win an election. That doesn’t entail a rejection of socialism’s traditional values: but it does mean that its appeal, and hence its policies, must address a much wider range of interests. ”
“ The trick for Labour is not to follow them and abandon the notion of government and collective provision: but to re-fashion it so that real power is exercised by people and not by institutions or bureaucracies. The fundamental error of Dr Owen (and, oddly, of David Steel since the election, though not before it) has been to surrender to Mrs Thatcher’s philosophy and say that power can only be devolved through the market. The 1990s will not see the continuing triumph of the market, but its failure. ”

Roy Hattersley: http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2001/jun/24/labour2001to2005.news
“ Tony Blair discovered a big idea. His destiny is to create a meritocracy. Unfortunately meritocracy is not the form of society which social democrats want to see. ... A Labour government should not be talking about escape routes from poverty and deprivation. By their nature they are only available to a highly-motivated minority. The Labour Party was created to change society in such a way that there is no poverty and deprivation from which to escape . ... The certain knowledge that the Conservative Party would be a worse government than Labour is not enough to sustain what used to be a party of principles. ... At this moment Labour stands for very little that can be identified with social democracy ”

Quote: : You got it! The dealer can only start a DROS 30 days after the "application" to DROS the the first handgun was entered into the system. Because the gun was hard to find the OP paid for it as well as the first. The wife is only going to do the paperwork so that the OP doesn't have to wait out the 30 days for her to DROS gun #2. Sure, there is nothing wrong with him paying for both and waiting the 30 days to DROS gun #2 for himself, but having the wife come in and "buy" it just so the husband doesn't have to wait is begging for trouble.
You don't have to convince anyone that you are confused. Your interpretation of what he is doing boggles the imagination . . . running an errand for someone is BS. . . he mentioned waiting the 30 days to put it in his name for the simple reason that the gun is for him and not his wife . . . that he thought that what you call "dropping off a deposit" was buyhing the gun evidences his intention to buy it for himself . . . there is no face to face if the wife does the DROS application since she is not the actual buyer. At this point the release of the deposit to the husband and payment by the wife would only establish that they realized they were in violation and an attempt to conceal the same. While you are comfortable just calling people liars. I would simply state the facts that are relevant to the issue. His actual motivations are simply none of my business, and unless he somehow creates hard evidence of trying to circumvent the system, none of your suspicions would stand up in court.
He won't end up in jail just because someone heard a rumor that he liked the gun that his wife ended up buying. His admiration for the gun doesn't disqualify her from purchasing it.
Even Abramski would not have been convicted if he had bought the gun and decided when he got home that he didn't like the grips. That is a perfectly reasonable explanation that has certainly happened legitimately on occasion. That case revolved basically on the fact that he admitted to lying on the form and said he didn't think it mattered and that a check from his uncle was written two days before he even bought the gun and said "Glock 19" on it proving that he never intended to keep the gun when he bought it.
The case never would have gone anywhere based on suspicion. It was the hard evidence that got him in trouble.
